response.answer_text: In almost every state, the best option will be your major state school in state. I grew up in Washington, so UW was mine. Someone from California would do best at Berkeley, a person in Texas at UTA, and so on. Even “backups” are often better in state. If a Texan got their degree from University of Houston, they’ll still get a great education. Maybe it won’t be as good as if they spent a fortune for another school, but it’ll be good enough at a fraction of the price. The exceptions to me is that if a person can’t get into a really decent in-state school, but they can get into a great school out of state (e.g. UTA rejects a candidate but MIT accepts them for some reason) then it’s not super affordable, but it’s worth the money.

If you are in state, Berkeley, SUNY stony brook, or GATech happen to give fantastic educations at ridiculously low costs. If you are applying out of state or as a foreigner, I doubt the 1–5k differences in cost per semester will make too much of a dent on the 200k of debt you can wrack up. You’ll likely want a scholarship. I’ve heard that Harvard is very good about giving scholarships. Otherwise, 79 Colleges with Full Ride Scholarships is a list of schools that have scholarships you can win, and you’re likely best off picking the ones you have the best shot at.
